title: 112_s2228
content: The Act is titled the "Yerington Land Conveyance and Sustainable Development Act." It includes findings related to the act. Congress finds that the city of Yerington, Nevada has the highest unemployment rate in the state at 16 percent. Efforts have been made for over 4 years to develop a sustainable plan for commercial and industrial development, mining, recreation, and community events on adjacent private land. This plan involves the conveyance of certain Federal land to the city at fair market value. The Federal land to be conveyed to the City under the sustainable development plan is adjacent to the City's boundaries and would be used to enhance recreational, cultural, commercial, and industrial development opportunities, as well as for future economic development and as an open space buffer to the City. The Federal land would enable commercial and industrial development, providing infrastructure services, tax revenue, and thousands of high-paying jobs for the City and County. Lyon County Commission and the City unanimously support the conveyance of the land. The Lyon County Commission and the City unanimously support the conveyance of Federal land for long-term economic and industrial development. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "City" refers to Yerington, Nevada. The term "Federal land" refers to land in Lyon County and Mineral County, Nevada, identified on the map as "City of Yerington Sustainable Development Conveyance Lands". The term "map" refers to the map titled "Yerington Land Conveyance and Sustainable Development Act" dated February 16, 2012. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary is required to convey Federal land to the City of Yerington within 90 days of the Act's enactment, in exchange for fair market value consideration. The fair market value is determined through an appraisal following federal standards. The City of Yerington must adhere to federal appraisal standards and regulations when developing and conducting activities on the conveyed Federal land. The City is responsible for all administrative costs associated with the conveyance of the land. The map of the land must be available for public inspection at the Bureau of Land Management offices.
